I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) for the Third Primary Education 
Development Project1 is included in the country operations business plan, 2012–2014.2 The 
Government  of  Bangladesh,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  and  eight  development 
partners3 have jointly developed the Third Primary Education Development Program, which has 
several innovative features.4 The project provides financing depending on the achievement of 
selected  results—called  disbursement-linked  indicators  (DLIs)—and  the  government  and 
development  partners  have  agreed  on  a  joint  mechanism  to  review,  verify,  and  improve 
reporting on DLIs and other results. Because ADB and the development partners use the 
government’s  treasury  system  for  project  disbursement  and  financial  management,  close 
fiduciary oversight and support for system improvement in public financial management (PFM) 
was also agreed. Subsequently, the government has requested ADB’s support to strengthen 
project  management  in  the  areas  of  fiduciary  risk  management,  and  result  reporting  and 
verification. The TA was further discussed and agreed during a joint fiduciary review in March 
2012. 5  The  government  concurred  with  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bangladesh has made significant achievement in increasing the participation of boys 
and girls in primary education. The major remaining, systemic challenges—reducing dropout 
and repetition, and improving the quality of education, particularly in disadvantaged areas—are 
addressed by the National Education Policy (NEP),6 which aims to reduce disparities between 
different  types  of  schools,  and  expand  and  improve  primary  education  in  disadvantaged 
locations in rural communities and urban slums. The Second Primary Education Development 
Program,  2003–2011  largely  contributed  to  achieving  the  Millennium  Development  Goal 
pertaining to primary education participation.7 This program also initiated key reforms to improve 
the quality of, and governance and management in, education. For instance, the introduction of 
results-based management has led to the publication of an annual sector performance report 
that helps monitor progress on key performance indicators and primary school quality standards. 
This focus on results-based management has also increased awareness of the importance of 
planning for and reporting on results, rather than inputs and activities. The project builds on the 
Second Primary Education Development Program’s achievements and experiences to pursue 
the government’s reform agenda in primary education, in line with the NEP objectives. 
 
3.  Focus on results. Lessons drawn from the previous program show that success in 
managing reforms in large systems—such as the Bangladesh primary education  system—

depends largely on the government’s capacity to effectively target, plan, and manage resources 
to achieve the intended results. As a consequence, the Third Primary Education Development 
Project has shifted from a project approach (with a focus on activities and inputs) to a broader 
program approach (with a focus on results). The project intends to develop institutional capacity 
in planning and financing based on results, to help establish a robust monitoring and evaluation 
system, and to promote accountability through improved result reporting. The project focuses on 
achieving outputs in four areas: (i) improved teaching and learning for all, (ii) reduced disparities 
in access and participation, (iii) decentralized and effective organization, and (iv) improved 
planning and management. The project’s financing depends on the government achieving a set 
of nine annual DLIs, which are outputs deemed essential to meeting the project’s objectives. 
The  nine  DLIs  have  been  selected  as  results  that  are  realistic,  under  the  control  of  the 
responsible agencies, and verifiable. A 5-year DLI matrix defining the annual DLIs has been 
developed, along with a detailed protocol, and mechanisms for government reporting on DLI 
achievement and independent verification from the development partners. The independent 
verification mechanism is intended to give assurance to the government and development 
partners regarding the accuracy of the DLI reports, and help develop system capacity in data 
collection, analysis, and result reporting. 
 
4.   Use  of  country  system  and  fiduciary  risk  management.  The  fiduciary  risk 
assessment,  which  was  undertaken  during  project  preparation,  advised  ADB  and  other 
development partners to use the government’s treasury system for disbursement and financial 
management.  The  ADB  loan  and  development  partners’  funds  are  channeled  to  the 
government’s treasury to finance eligible project expenditures, which are included under defined 
program budget headings in the government’s chart of accounts. One of the conditions for 
disbursement from ADB and development partners is timely submission of accurate quarterly 
interim  unaudited  financial  reports  generated  by  the  government  integrated  budget  and 
accounting  system.  Therefore,  the  fiduciary  risk  assessment  conducted  during  preparation 
focused on the government’s PFM system and identified risks associated with government 
management of funds and accounting for project expenditures. These include, for instance, 
payment  processing  time,  reconciliation  of  accounts,  and  segregation  of  advances  from 
expenditures. A PFM action plan was developed to manage the financial management risks in 
accounting, auditing, and procurement. Periodic monitoring of the implementation of the PFM 
action plan and updating of the required actions support improved governance and better 
practices in PFM and provide assurance that funds are being used for the intended purpose and 
are accounted for. The government and development partners agreed on a mechanism for 
close fiduciary oversight and support for system improvement in PFM through regular review of 
procurement and financial management activities by the joint procurement and finance working 
group (PFWG) of the government and the project development partners. It also comprises 
quarterly  and  annual  fiduciary  reviews  (AFRs),  which  focus  on  selected  areas  of  system 
improvement in PFM. ADB and the International Development Association have been tasked 
with  managing  project  joint  fiduciary  oversight,  including  financing  and  joint  technical 
supervision of the work of the consultants.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
5.  The TA will support NEP objectives to achieve education for all by 2015, particularly in 
the area of good governance and capacity development. It will support project management in 
the areas of fiduciary risk management and result reporting and verification. 
                                                
8  Fiduciary oversight arrangements and procurement arrangements are described in Annex IX of the Joint Financing 
Arrangement signed by the government and development partners in December 2011.

3 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The expected impact is an efficient, inclusive, and equitable primary education system in 
Bangladesh. The impact will be measured through changes in (i) the net primary enrollment 
rate, (ii) gender parity index for gross primary enrolment, (iii) completion rate, and (iv) number of 
input years per graduate.  The impact of the TA is based on the outcome expected at the end of 
the project. 
 
7.  The expected outcome is an increased assurance regarding fiduciary concerns and 
result reporting for the project. The TA aims to ensure that funds are used efficiently and 
effectively to achieve the intended results and are accounted for. Outcomes will be measured 
through: (i) agreed actions for 2012 of the PFM action plan being fully implemented by May 
2013, and (ii) result reporting fully meeting the protocol agreed through the September 2012 DLI 
verification. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The first output is improved fiduciary risk management. The TA will support quarterly and 
annual fiduciary reviews. The quarterly fiduciary reviews (QFRs) focus on reviewing government 
quarterly  interim  unaudited  financial  reports,  testing  implementation  of  the  government 
integrated budget and accounting system, and quarterly procurement reviews. The AFRs will be 
conducted annually from October to March, for the duration of the TA (see para. 11 and footnote 
10), and will review the annual financial statement and the report of the auditor-general. Based 
on the outcomes of the QFRs, the AFR will include an in-depth review of specific fiduciary risks 
areas, which will be identified annually. The selection of the areas for in-depth review under the 
AFR will be confirmed during the project joint annual review missions (JARMs) in May, and may 
include,  for  instance,  a  review  of  payment  processing,  including  sample  testing  using 
information from the integrated budget and accounting system generated reports and cash 
books of a sample of drawing and disbursement offices. Another area of review under the AFR 
may be the delivery of stipends to primary schools children. The AFR also includes a post-
procurement review; this will require about 50% of the consultant’s inputs, because it will assess 
compliance  with  the  agreed  procurement  processes  and  cover  a  sample  of  15%–20%  of 
contracts awarded during the year. The government and development partners will agree on a 
periodic update of the PFM action plan based on the outcomes of the QFRs and AFRs. 
 
9.  The second output is the improved result reporting and data verification process. The TA 
will support an independent verification of DLI achievement reports in selected areas. This 
includes assessment of administrative and technical documents and data submitted by the 
government, and field verification on a sample basis. The methodology of the independent 
verification will be confirmed during the JARM, and the assessment will be conducted annually 
from  July  to  August,  for  the  duration  of  the  TA  activities.  The  result  of  the  independent 
verification  will  enable  the  government  and  development  partners  to  agree  on  the  DLI 
achievement in a joint decision-making meeting in September. 
 
10.  The third output is the enhanced policy dialogue on system capacity development in 
PFM, results-based planning, financing, and reporting. Other key areas of policy reforms may 
be identified during the JARM, such as public–private partnerships and decentralization. The TA 
will  support  workshops,  seminars,  and  studies  for  knowledge  sharing,  policy  reviews,  and 
planning for institutional capacity development in PFM; results-based planning, financing, and 
reporting; and other key areas that may be identified.

4   
11.  The TA builds on the results of the small-scale TA for Support for the Proposed Primary 
Education Sector Development Program,9 which helped identify and plan critical activities in the 
areas of PFM and result reporting. Other development partners will provide complementary TA 
in the area of results monitoring and reporting. It is planned that additional resources from ADB 
and cofinancing partners will extend and expand TA activities in the subsequent years of the 
project in line with the following expected outputs: (i) carrying out QFRs and AFRs, as well as 
special audits and public expenditure tracking surveys, as and if required; (ii) independent 
verification of DLI achievement reports in selected areas; and (iii) seminars and studies for 
knowledge sharing, policy reviews, and planning for institutional capacity development in PFM; 
results-based planning, financing, and reporting; and other key areas identified. 
 
12.  Improved  institutional  capacity  in  PFM  and  results-based  planning,  financing,  and 
reporting will lead to better targeting, more effective use of funds, and good governance. This 
will result in increased sector performance. High turnover of staff and lack of a conducive 
political environment to improve system capacity are risks that may undermine institutional 
capacity development. Close oversight by ADB and other development partners and extensive 
policy dialogue would help overcome such risks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The government has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). No financing 
is expected from the government. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The Ministry of Primary and Mass Education will be the executing agency of the TA, and 
will work in close consultation with the comptroller general of account under the Ministry of 
Finance, particularly in the area of financial management. 
 
15.  The TA will be conducted over a period of 12 months from the fielding of consultants, 
which is anticipated in July 2012.10 Therefore, the TA is expected to be completed in September 
2013. The TA will engage 8 person-months of international and 18 person-months of national 
consultant services. ADB will recruit an audit firm to conduct the AFRs using bio-data technical 
proposal for the quality- and cost-based selection method (quality-cost ratio of 80:20). The firm 
will  provide  4  person-months  of  international  and  12  person-months  of  national  consulting 
services in financial audit and procurement audit. In addition, ADB will engage 3 person-months 
of international consulting services on an individual basis in PFM, and education monitoring and 
evaluation. Provision for a pool of 1 person-month of international and 6 person-months of 
national  consulting  services  to  be recruited  individually  is  kept for flexibility.  Their  area of 
expertise will be defined when the need arises within the TA output areas. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. All recruitment will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under the TA will be  made in accordance with ADB’s  Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
                                                
9  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for Support for the Proposed Primary 
Education Sector Development Program. Manila (approved on 16 December). 
10 Extension and expansion of TA is foreseen when additional financing from ADB or cofinancing from other 
development partners becomes available.

5 
16.  The TA  will  be  monitored  periodically  through a  review  of  consultants’  reports  and 
meetings of the PFWG of the project consortium of development partners. TA effectiveness will 
be evaluated by ADB, and adjustment will be made as required, in close consultation with the 
PFWG. Lessons and best practices will be disseminated through the aide memoires of the 
project JARMs and the uploading of selected reports on the project website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for the Support for the Third Primary Education Development 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will help the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other 
development  partners  to  closely  oversee  management  of  the  Third  Primary  Education 
Development Project,1 particularly with respect to (i) fiduciary risk management, and (ii) results 
reporting and verification. It will help ensure compliance of the Government of Bangladesh with 
the agreed disbursement conditions, and that funds are accounted for and used effectively for 
the  intended  purpose.  In  addition,  the  TA  will  further  contribute  to  institutional  capacity 
development in public financial management (PFM); results-based planning, financing, and 
reporting; and other key reforms as required. 
 
B.  Specific Consultancy Inputs 
 
  1.  Annual Fiduciary Reviews (and Other Special Audits and Surveys) 
 
2.  The  consultants  will  undertake  an  annual  fiduciary  review  (AFR)  of  the  project  in 
accordance with the terms of reference, which will be finalized every year by ADB and the 
International Development Association.2 The AFR will consist of a post-procurement review, and 
an in-depth review of 2–3 specific risk areas. These will be defined every year and may include: 
 
(i)  payment  processing,  including  sample  testing  using  information  from  the 
integrated budget and accounting system (IBAS) reports and cash books of a 
sample of drawing and disbursement offices (DDOs); 
(ii)  reconciliation between IBAS and DDO cash books and ledgers using the IBAS 
reports on reconciliation, including review of DDOs financial management; 
(iii)  internal controls over payroll processing and personnel data management; 
(iv)  release procedures for funding to schools and related financial management; 
(v)  stipends delivery; and 
(vi)  analysis of recurring audit observations that can lead to systemic improvements. 
 
3.  An audit firm (or an institution with relevant expertise) will be selected annually using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method (80:20) and bio-data technical proposals. The audit 
firm  will  employ  adequate  staff  with  appropriate  professional  qualifications  and  suitable 
experience with the International Federation of Accountants standards, in particular international 
standards on auditing, and International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions standards, 
and with experience in performing assessments of programs comparable in size and complexity 
to the project. Indicative consultants’ inputs for one AFR are: 
 
(i)  Financial audit specialist and team leader (international, 2 person-months). 
The team leader nominated by the firm shall: (a) have at least a graduate degree 
in financial management or be a certified accountant; (b) be a member of a 
recognized accountancy professional body; (c) have experience from or work 
with a company affiliated to an international audit firm; (d) have experience with 
the Government of Bangladesh financial management system, procedures, and 
regulations applying to central government, district, and upazila (block) levels; (e)

(ii)  Procurement audit specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist

administration, or related discipline; (b) at least 5 years of experience in public

(iii)  Financial  audit  specialists  (2  national,  6  person-months;  3  person-months

funded  projects,  as  accountants  in  Bangladesh.  Experience  with  financial 
management  reviews  in  accordance  with  the  guidelines  from  multilateral

(iv)  Procurement audit specialists (2 national, 6 person-months; 3 person-months 
each).  The  specialists  shall  have  (a)  at  least  graduate  degrees  in  public 
administration, business administration, or other related disciplines and (b) at 
least 5 years experience in public and private procurement and capacity building 
in  procurement.  Experience  working  with  procurement  guidelines  from 
multilateral organizations in relation to the national government’s procurement 
guidelines is highly preferred. 
 
2.  Quarterly Fiduciary Reviews, Results Reporting, and Others 
 
4.  Individual consultants will be engaged for the following positions: (i)  PFM specialist 
(international, 2 person-months); and (ii) monitoring and evaluation specialist (international, 1 
person-month). 
 
5.  Public  financial  management  specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
specialist shall have (i) at least a graduate degree in accounting, business administration, public 
administration,  economics,  or  other  related  disciplines,  (ii)  at  least  10  years  of  relevant 
experience in financial management, especially in the public sector, and (iii) at least 5 years of 
experience working in PFM in developing countries. Experience working in Bangladesh is a 
strong asset. The specialist will: 
 
(i)  Conduct the quarterly fiduciary review (QFR) in accordance with the QFR’s terms 
of reference and any revision to the terms of reference that may be agreed with 
ADB and the World Bank. 
(ii)  Identify and analyze key fiduciary concerns that may arise from the outcomes of 
the  QFR  and  advise  on  remedial  measures.  In  doing  so,  liaise  with  the 
procurement experts to include the outcomes of their procurement reviews. 
(iii)  Review quarterly interim financial reports and advise on any concerns that may 
arise. 
(iv)  Based on outcomes of the QFR and assessment of the PFM action plan, assist 
in identifying key themes for the AFR. 
(v)  Assist  in  reviewing  and  updating  the  PFM  action  plan  agreed  upon  during 
appraisal. 
(vi)  Assist in preparing a public expenditure tracking survey, as required.

development. 
(ix)  Recommend  actions  for  system  capacity  development  and  help  organize 
seminars, studies, and policy reviews. 
 
6.  Education monitoring and evaluation specialist (international, 1 person-month). The 
specialist shall have (i) at least a graduate degree in education, sociology, public administration, 
economics, or other related discipline; (ii) at least 10 years of relevant experience in monitoring 
and evaluation in the education sector; and (iii) at least 5 years of relevant experience in 
monitoring and evaluation in developing countries.  Experience working in Bangladesh is a 
strong asset. The specialist will: 
 
(i)  review DLI achievement reports in selected areas and advise on compliance of 
the reports with the agreed protocol; 
(ii)  review  administrative  and  technical  documents  and  data  submitted  by  the 
government, verify accuracy of data, and analyze information gaps; 
(iii)  conduct field verification, as required; 
(iv)  make  recommendations  for  improved  results  reporting  and  capacity 
development; and 
(v)  recommend  actions  for  system  capacity  development,  and  help  organize 
seminars, studies, and policy reviews. 
 
7.  Funds will be retained to support a pool of individual consultants (international, 1 person-
month; and national, 6 person-months) whose areas of expertise will be defined as the need 
arises within the TA outputs areas. 
 
8.  The cost breakdown is in Table A3.
